results.title: The Fallen idol. The Winslow boy
results.creator_credit: London Film Productions, Anatole de Grunwald, Anthony Asquith, Terence Rattigan, Carol Reed and Graham Greene
results.brief_description:
Based on a true incident, ‘The Winslow Boy’ (produced by Anatole de Grunwald, directed by Anthony Asquith) tells the simple story of a father’s impassioned fight to clear the name of his son - a young naval cadet expelled from college after being found guilty of theft. Arthur Winslow is certain of his son’s innocence, and yet is impeded in his task to retain the boy’s honour, that is until a famous KC and political leader, Sir Robert Morton, agree to help their cause. Cast includes Robert Donat, Cedric Hardwicke and Margaret Leighton.
Based on a short story by Graham Greene, ‘The Fallen idol’ (produced and directed by Carol Reed) is a sensitive study of the way in which a young boy interprets the strange and seemingly illogical behaviour of the adults who surround him. He witnesses the adulterous relationship that develops between the butler Baines, whom he worships, and a typist at the foreign embassy in London where his father works. He also sees Baines’ wife fall to her death while spying on the couple and the boy’s interpretation of events places Baines in a perilous situation. Cast includes Michele Morgan, Ralph Richardson, Sonia Dresdel and Jack Hawkins.

results.title: The Fallen idol [study extract]
results.brief_description: The excerpt covers the following: Baines, Julie and Felipe and a day of stolen happiness with a riotous game of hide and seek in the empty Embassy, not knowing that Mrs Baines is spying on them. Felipe is awakened later by Mrs Baines who tries to involve him in her plot against her husband. The terrified boy witnesses a violent struggling quarrel between husband and wife, and believes that Baines has killed his wife. He rushes into the night in his pyjamas but is apprehended and taken in charge by a friendly policeman. The extract is chosen to illustrate Reed’s style, his ability to handle actors, (especially the child), the use of a large number of shots and quick cutting back and forth, imaginative lighting and the creation of suspense.

results.title: The Fall of the Roman Empire
results.creator_credit: Samuel Bronston Productions, Samuel Bronston and Anthony Mann
results.brief_description: In second century Rome Emperor Marcus Aurelius plans to make the heir to the throne his adopted son Livius, rather than his biological son Commodus. Indignant with rage, Commodus has his father murdered and succeeds him, declaring himself a God. When Commodus discovers that his sister, Lucilla has a stronger claim to the throne than he, Commodus sentences her to burn at the stake. This sword-and-sandal epic harked back to successful 1950s biblical dramas with its lavish sets, scores of extras, remarkable action sequences and a chariot race. The exorbitant cost of the film (and poor audience reception) financially ruined producer Samuel Bronston. It has been speculated that audiences were tiring of such lavish productions and timing may have also hurt the film’s box-office - it was released the same year as the opulent Burton/Taylor epic “Cleopatra”. Cast includes Sophia Loren, Christopher Plummer, Alec Guinness, Omar Sharif and James Mason.

results.title: The Fall of Communism as seen in gay pornography
results.brief_description: Using excerpts, shots and screen tests from pornography produced in Eastern Europe and Russia, this startling documentary refutes the libertarian aesthetics of much of western queer politics. By forcing us to contemplate the faces of the young male models, it reminds us that even with the fall of communism, materialism and history still have a place in our thinking about film.

results.title: The Fall and rise of Marla's eyes
results.brief_description:
A twisted tale about a little girl named Marla who lives in a small town named Glebe. Marla has an odd hobby, an obsession - she collects human eyes.
Presented as an interactive on-line storybook illustrated by Alexandra Zhadan and written by N.J. Hunter.

results.title: The Falcon and the snowman
results.creator_credit: Orion Pictures Corporation, Gabriel Katzka and John Schlesinger
results.brief_description: A seminary drop out and aimless youth, Christopher Boyce (Timothy Hutton) is an average American who commences work at RTX as a sensitive document handler. Chris is quickly earmarked for something significant, working with the CIA in monitoring special projects. Occasionally he also intercepts misrouted secret mail. Disillusioned with the deceptions he comes across, Chris enlists the help of his (originally reluctant) drug dealing best friend Andrew Daulton Lee (Sean Penn) to act as go between in selling secrets to the Russian KGB. Lee’s dealings with the KGB are mainly with a Russian spy (David Suchet) who doesn’t underestimate the naivete of the people he is dealing with and is quick to raise the stakes in what he’s willing to pay for. Lee, high on his addiction to crack and being flush with money to support his habit, attempts to subvert the exchanges to his advantage and is liberal in sharing their secret with all and sundry - jeopardising his friendship and their discovery. Based on a true story and set against a backdrop of Nixon’s impeachment, the film has been read as a metaphor for the disillusion felt throughout America in the 1970s and the search for meaning in a time of Vietnam, the Cold War and political mistrust, balanced against advances in space exploration and artistic and sexual freedom. Cast also includes Pat Hingle, Joyce Van Patten and Lori Singer.

results.title: The Fairy faith
results.creator_credit: John Walker Productions, ONF | NFB, John Walker and Kent Martin
results.brief_description: Fairies, fair folk, elves, trolls, pixies, brownies, goblins… Before being relegated to the realm of childhood fantasy by the scientific thinking of Victorian times, fairies existed as part of a rich and ancient belief system practised in many cultures. Filmmaker John Walker investigates the continued appeal of fairy lore in a world obsessed with materialism and rational thinking in this beautifully filmed documentary filled with the stunning landscapes that have fuelled tales of fairy folk for generations. He travels to the moors of England, the Highlands of Scotland, and sacred sites within Ireland and Cape Breton, discussing the origins of fairy lore, sightings of “the little people” and modern attitudes to the fairy faith. Walker interviews artist Brian Froud and reveals the inspiration for his fairy artworks, discusses the reality and physical possibility of fairies with scholar in seeing the paranormal Dr. Mark Fox, and meets Eddie Lenihan, a storyteller who saves an old fairy thorn tree from being destroyed by town developers.
